articles.headline: Glare of Fires Pulls Migrants From Shadows
articles.snippet: The California fires exposed the often-invisible existence of illegal immigrants in ways that were sometimes deadly.
articles.abstract: The California fires exposed the often-invisible existence of illegal immigrants in ways that were sometimes deadly.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 26 — Out of the burning brush, from behind canyon rocks, several immigrants bolted toward a group of firefighters, chased not by the border police but by the onrush of flames from one of the biggest wildfires this week.
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Will Carless

articles.headline: This Time, Housing Is Taking Department Stores Down With It
articles.snippet: Since April, when investors voiced optimism that the housing slide had been contained, shares of the country’s biggest department store chains have fallen by about 30 percent.
articles.abstract: Since April, when investors voiced optimism that the housing slide had been contained, shares of the country’s biggest department store chains have fallen by about 30 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: When home builders’ stocks plunged in 2006, Wall Street was confident that the problems would not spill over into the larger economy. Exhibit A? Department store stocks rose steadily despite the housing woes.
articles.byline: By Floyd Norris and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Merrill Lynch Weighs Ouster of Top Officer
articles.snippet: Directors of the brokerage firm have begun to consider whether to replace the embattled E. Stanley O’Neal, and with whom.
articles.abstract: Directors of the brokerage firm have begun to consider whether to replace the embattled E. Stanley O’Neal, and with whom.
articles.lead_paragraph: The board of Merrill Lynch, its frustration mounting over the brokerage firm’s credit losses and the decision-making of its embattled chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, has begun to actively consider whether to replace him and with whom, according to people briefed on the board’s deliberations.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Countrywide Has Big Loss but Upbeat Forecast
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer reported a $1.2 billion loss in the third quarter of 2007 but said that it expected to return to profitability by the end of the year.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer reported a $1.2 billion loss in the third quarter of 2007 but said that it expected to return to profitability by the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, reported a $1.2 billion loss yesterday for the third quarter of 2007 but said that it expected to return to profitability by the end of the year as the housing crisis subsides and it capitalizes on disruptions in the home loan market.

articles.headline: Execution Case Tests Iraq’s Bid to Ease Divide
articles.snippet: The fate of Iraq’s former minister of defense will turn on the ability of Iraq’s fractious sects and political alliances to work together.
articles.abstract: The fate of Iraq’s former minister of defense will turn on the ability of Iraq’s fractious sects and political alliances to work together.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 26 — In late June, three of Saddam Hussein’s senior military officials were found guilty of war crimes, including the notorious henchman known as Chemical Ali. Iraqi law required that they be executed no more than 30 days after the Iraqi courts rejected their final appeals.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: 1944 Conviction of Black G.I.’s Is Ruled Flawed
articles.snippet: A ruling this week by a U.S. Army panel could lead to the overturning of one of the largest courts-martial of World War II.
articles.abstract: A ruling this week by a U.S. Army panel could lead to the overturning of one of the largest courts-martial of World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, Oct. 26 — Guglielmo Olivotto, an Italian prisoner of war, died with a noose around his neck, lynched at a military post on Puget Sound 63 years ago. Samuel Snow, 83, hopes that people will stop blaming him and the 27 other black soldiers convicted of starting the riot that led to Mr. Olivotto’s death. It was one of the largest Army courts-martial of World War II.

articles.headline: Technology, the Stealthy Tattletale
articles.snippet: A technological revolution is making it possible not just to track down escaping bank robbers but to find missing things and people far more quickly and precisely than ever.
articles.abstract: A technological revolution is making it possible not just to track down escaping bank robbers but to find missing things and people far more quickly and precisely than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Initially, it seemed like an easy bank robbery. After stealing $7,000 from a PNC Bank in Evendale, Ohio, Kenneth Maples climbed into a white Ford pickup driven by his wife, Jewell, according to a police report. No dye pack exploded, no police sirens screamed in pursuit as the couple’s truck slipped into the anonymity of heavy traffic on Interstate 71 just after 10 a.m. on Sept. 14.

articles.headline: U.S. Airlines Put Off Buying New Planes
articles.snippet: The nation’s fleet of commercial planes is aging as carriers put off buying more comfortable and fuel-efficient jets.
articles.abstract: The nation’s fleet of commercial planes is aging as carriers put off buying more comfortable and fuel-efficient jets.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not just flights that are being delayed. United States airlines are also putting off purchases of new planes, meaning the nation’s fleet of aircraft, on average, is aging right along with the passengers.

articles.headline: Despite Oil, Shares Rise in Wild Ride
articles.snippet: The price of crude oil hit another record high yesterday, capping a wild week on Wall Street, punctuated by widespread rumors and violent market swings.
articles.abstract: The price of crude oil hit another record high yesterday, capping a wild week on Wall Street, punctuated by widespread rumors and violent market swings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of crude oil hit another record high yesterday, capping a wild week on Wall Street, punctuated by widespread rumors and violent market swings.

articles.headline: Rethinking Fire Policy in the Tinderbox Zone
articles.snippet: Many California residents are ruggedly obstinate about the choice they have made to live with the constant threat of fire.
articles.abstract: Many California residents are ruggedly obstinate about the choice they have made to live with the constant threat of fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 27 — As Californians sift through the cinders of this week’s deadly wildfires, there is a growing consensus that the state’s war against such disasters — as it is currently being fought — cannot be won.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and Jesse McKinley

articles.headline: Guesstimates Won’t Cut It Anymore
articles.snippet: As firms do the real math, losses related to mortgages could pile up.
articles.abstract: As firms do the real math, losses related to mortgages could pile up.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE props holding up the values of risky mortgage securities finally started to give way last week. And that means the $30 billion in losses and write-downs taken by big brokerage firms in the third quarter are not likely to be the last.

articles.headline: From the Toy Box to the Streets
articles.snippet: Outlandish garb earns smiles, and hazard pay, for actors willing to dress up as foodstuffs, cartoon characters and power tools.
articles.abstract: Outlandish garb earns smiles, and hazard pay, for actors willing to dress up as foodstuffs, cartoon characters and power tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS year’s “Christmas in Little Italy” street festival begins late next month, but if Robyn Stein attends, it will be as just another face in the crowd — not as a huge string cheese.

articles.headline: After Succeeding, Young Tycoons Try, Try Again
articles.snippet: Having already struck it rich, many young Internet tycoons throw themselves back into a start-up, in a competition with one another and themselves.
articles.abstract: Having already struck it rich, many young Internet tycoons throw themselves back into a start-up, in a competition with one another and themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Max Levchin is not easily distracted from his work.

articles.headline: Obama Promises a Forceful Stand Against Clinton
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama said he would start confronting Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton more forcefully, in response to concerns about his lack of assertiveness.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama said he would start confronting Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton more forcefully, in response to concerns about his lack of assertiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 27 — Senator Barack Obama says he will start confronting Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton more forcefully, declaring that she had not been candid in describing her views on critical issues, as he tries to address mounting alarm among supporters that his lack of assertiveness has allowed her to dominate the presidential race.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: The Survivor
articles.snippet: Intense and imposing, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the chief executive of Lehman Brothers, is trying to lead the firm through one of Wall Street’s worst calamities in years.
articles.abstract: Intense and imposing, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the chief executive of Lehman Brothers, is trying to lead the firm through one of Wall Street’s worst calamities in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a winter night at the Museum of Modern Art early last year, Richard S. Fuld Jr. addressed more than 135 newly anointed Lehman Brothers managing directors and senior executives, telling them, their spouses and partners exactly how he viewed the landscape on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Iraq Hampers U.S. Bid to Widen Sunni Police Role
articles.snippet: Efforts to recruit Sunni policemen have been met with halfhearted support and outright resistance from the Shiite-dominated national government.
articles.abstract: Efforts to recruit Sunni policemen have been met with halfhearted support and outright resistance from the Shiite-dominated national government.
articles.lead_paragraph: HABBANIYA, Iraq  The American military’s push to organize Sunni Arabs into local neighborhood watch groups has been one of the United States’ most important initiatives in Iraq  so much so that President Bush flew to Anbar Province in September to highlight growing alliances with Sunni tribal leaders.

articles.headline: Weary of Highway Bribery, Russians Take On the Police
articles.snippet: The beating of a leader of a budding movement to uphold motorists’ rights in the face of police corruption has prompted an outcry.
articles.abstract: The beating of a leader of a budding movement to uphold motorists’ rights in the face of police corruption has prompted an outcry.
articles.lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia, Oct. 25 — Kirill Formanchuk, like almost everyone who drives in Russia, was used to being pulled over by the police and cited for seemingly trumped up infractions. Yet instead of resigning himself to paying a bribe, he turned traffic stops into roadside tribunals, interrogating officers about their grasp of the law, recording the events and filing formal complaints about them.

articles.headline: If It’s Retail, Is It Still Rock?
articles.snippet: From perfumes to pool cues, branding for musicians has no bounds.
articles.abstract: From perfumes to pool cues, branding for musicians has no bounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS torrents of money streamed into his wallet from multiplatinum albums in the 1980s and 1990s, Duff McKagan, then the bass player for the hard rock band Guns N’ Roses, had little interest in tracking his cash. Instead, he relied on intimidation and his group’s reputation as the “most dangerous band in the world” to prevent managers from ripping him off.

articles.headline: An Advocate for TV That Viewers Create
articles.snippet: While Current TV has gained a lot of attention, mainly because of Al Gore’s involvement, it is not clear that the cable channel is attracting an audience.
articles.abstract: While Current TV has gained a lot of attention, mainly because of Al Gore’s involvement, it is not clear that the cable channel is attracting an audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after Al Gore learned that he would share the Nobel Peace Prize, he took to the stage at a conference in Phoenix and delivered an impassioned speech. But he never referred to the honor or to his global warming campaign. Instead, he was trying to drum up advertising interest in his media project, Current TV.

articles.headline: Risk-Taker’s Reign at Merrill Ends With Swift Fall
articles.snippet: E. Stanley O’Neal is expected to resign as early as Monday as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch.
articles.abstract: E. Stanley O’Neal is expected to resign as early as Monday as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: The six-year reign of E. Stanley O’Neal at Merrill Lynch has been one of contradictions. He was a loner in an industry that places a premium on relationships. And he pushed Merrill into risky investments despite his experience as chief financial officer, where assessing risk was one of his responsibilities.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Murdoch, a Folk Hero in Silicon
articles.snippet: The lack of correctness and, occasionally, business civility that makes Rupert Murdoch a nonmember of the club of Eastern elites makes him something of a folk hero on the left coast.
articles.abstract: The lack of correctness and, occasionally, business civility that makes Rupert Murdoch a nonmember of the club of Eastern elites makes him something of a folk hero on the left coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Web 2.0 Summit a few weeks ago, MySpace held an after-party at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. With a guest list of Silicon Valley luminaries and a party room redone in white — carpet, chairs, table and yes, mostly people — it was a very post-modern indication that MySpace, the social network owned by the News Corporation, was ready to engage with its brethren to the north by opening an office here.

articles.headline: In the Rugged North of Iraq, Kurdish Rebels Flout Turkey
articles.snippet: In a remote corner of northern Iraq, Kurdish militants fighting Turkey thrive, protected by mountains and a complex web of relationships.
articles.abstract: In a remote corner of northern Iraq, Kurdish militants fighting Turkey thrive, protected by mountains and a complex web of relationships.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANIYA, Iraq, Oct. 27 — A low-slung concrete building off a steep mountain road marks the beginning of rebel territory in this remote corner of northern Iraq. The fighters based here, Kurdish militants fighting Turkey, fly their own flag, and despite urgent international calls to curb them, they operate freely, receiving supplies in beat-up pickup trucks less than 10 miles from a government checkpoint.

articles.headline: Health Sector Puts Its Money on Democrats
articles.snippet: Democratic candidates for president are outpacing Republicans in donations from the health care industry.
articles.abstract: Democratic candidates for president are outpacing Republicans in donations from the health care industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  In a reversal from past election cycles, Democratic candidates for president are outpacing Republicans in donations from the health care industry, even as the leading Democrats in the field offer proposals that have caused deep anxiety in some of its sectors.
articles.byline: By Raymond Hernandez and Robert Pear

articles.headline: What Kind of Caution by the Fed This Time?
articles.snippet: When Federal Reserve policy makers meet on Wednesday to set interest rates, they will be paying less attention to what is happening to the economy than to what could happen.
articles.abstract: When Federal Reserve policy makers meet on Wednesday to set interest rates, they will be paying less attention to what is happening to the economy than to what could happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 — When policy makers at the Federal Reserve set interest rates on Wednesday, they will be paying less attention to what is happening to the economy than to what could happen.

articles.headline: Hulu Readies Its Online TV, Dodging the Insults
articles.snippet: Created by NBC and Fox to bring free television to the Web, Hulu plans to begin sending videos to its partners, Microsoft, AOL, MySpace, Yahoo and Comcast.
articles.abstract: Created by NBC and Fox to bring free television to the Web, Hulu plans to begin sending videos to its partners, Microsoft, AOL, MySpace, Yahoo and Comcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: The knives are out for Hulu.com.

articles.headline: Reimagining the Automobile Industry by Selling the Electricity
articles.snippet: A top Silicon Valley technologist has devised a plan to reinvent the auto industry around electric-powered cars by building battery-charging stations around the world.
articles.abstract: A top Silicon Valley technologist has devised a plan to reinvent the auto industry around electric-powered cars by building battery-charging stations around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 — Shai Agassi, a Silicon Valley technologist who was in competition to become chief executive of SAP, one of the world’s largest software companies, has re-emerged with a grand plan to reinvent the world’s automobile industry around battery-powered all-electric cars.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Set to End Sole Cable Deals for Apartments
articles.snippet: Hoping to reduce spiraling cable TV costs, the F.C.C. plans to strike down contracts giving cable companies exclusive rights to service individual apartment buildings.
articles.abstract: Hoping to reduce spiraling cable TV costs, the F.C.C. plans to strike down contracts giving cable companies exclusive rights to service individual apartment buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Federal Communications Commission, hoping to reduce the rising costs of cable television, is preparing to strike down thousands of contracts this week that gave individual cable companies exclusive rights to provide service to an apartment building, the agency’s chairman says.
